Modified metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) encapsulating new ionic N-heterocyclic-based functional groups, prepared via a ship-in-a-bottle approach, introduce a novel catalytic system for CO₂ conversion with epoxides. The MIL-101(Cr) framework was functionalized with novel ionic liquids (ILs) such as 1,5-bis(2-aminopyrimidinium)pentane bromide (2AMP-DBrP) and 1,5-bis(2-aminopyrimidinium)ethyl ether bromide (2AMP-DBrEE), resulting in cationic pyrimidinium-containing Cr-MOFs with free bromide ions, namely MIL101–2AMP-DBrP and MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE. Although the surface area (2456 and 2408 m²/g) and pore volume (1.44 and 1.41 cm³/g) of these encapsulated materials were reduced compared to pristine MIL-101(Cr) (3425 m²/g and 1.78 cm³/g), the CO₂ adsorption capacity at low pressure was notably increased (3.51 and 4.05 mmol g⁻¹ of CO₂). These modified MOFs demonstrated exceptional catalytic performance and stability in CO₂ fixation with various epoxides, achieving a high turnover frequency (TOF) of 82.5 h⁻¹ under mild conditions (0.1 MPa, 90 °C) without the need for co-catalysts or solvents, which are essential criteria for commercial viability. Moreover, in situ FTIR analysis suggests that the enhanced performance is due to CO₂ activation via carbamic acid formation facilitated by primary amino groups and epoxide activation through hydrogen bonding. This dual activation mechanism is critical for achieving high catalytic efficiency under mild conditions and underscores the innovative and significant advancements presented in this work compared to existing IL-MOFs. Graphical Abstract Keywords Metal-organic frameworks MIL-101(Cr) CO2 utilization Cyclic carbonate Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Technologies utilizing CO2 as a raw material for creating useful chemicals are seen as a viable approach to reduce the overall release of human-generated carbon dioxide into the atmosphere [1–7]. There are, however, many challenges to overcome for converting CO2 into valuable chemicals, with the most obvious being the high energy cost due to the inherent stability of CO2. An approach that has gained industrial importance in the past decade is the production of cyclic organic carbonates through the CO2 fixation reaction with epoxides [8–10]. This CO2 utilization process is a greener alternative to generate these useful molecules than typical carbonate synthesis industrial processes using phosgene and can be conducted under mild conditions of temperature and pressure, provided active catalysts are used. This cycloaddition reaction is particularly favorable from a thermodynamic standpoint, as the driving force relies on the release of the ring-strain energy present in the epoxide substrate [11]. Cyclic carbonates, which are typically in liquid form, exhibit high stability and serve as long-term reservoirs for CO2 sequestration when compared to other commonly used products like urea, which rapidly releases CO2 upon utilization in agricultural applications [12]. In addition, cyclic carbonates have various applications as electrolytes in batteries, serve as solvents in environmentally friendly chemical processes, contribute to the creation of eco-friendly polymers like polyurethanes and polycarbonates, and function as intermediates in diverse chemical reactions [13,14]. One class of highly active heterogeneous catalysts for CO2 fixation reactions is metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), which are crystalline materials created through the assembly of organic ligands with metal clusters or metal ions [15,16]. The distinguishing characteristics of MOFs include the ability to be structurally designed, the capacity to tune its porosity and to integrate task-specific functional groups into their framework, enabling catalysis for fine chemical synthesis. One of the most stable, tunable, and porous MOFs studied is MIL-101(Cr) [17,18], which has a rigid zeotype crystal structure comprised of two quasi-spherical cages of 34 Å and 29 Å in diameters with pentagonal and hexagonal windows of 16 Å and 12 Å in diameters, respectively [17–19]. The utilization of MIL-101(Cr) as a support for immobilizing homogeneous catalysts via chemical grafting has gained significant attention owing to its remarkable attributes, such as a high surface area and exceptional thermal stability [20,21]. It is therefore not surprising that many MOF catalysts have been used for CO2 fixation reactions [22–26]; however, the design of functional MOFs for CO2 fixation reactions under mild conditions, without the use of solvents and co-catalysts and operating at ambient pressure, remains a challenging endeavor [20,21,27–29]. One successful strategy for the formation of cyclic carbonate using CO2 is the immobilization of ionic liquids (IL) on heterogeneous structures, such as silica [30–32], chitosan [33], cross-linked polymers [34], magnetic nanoparticles [35], and carbon nanotubes [36]. The ILs consist of cationic and anionic moieties with various functional groups and possess interesting features, such as negligible vapor pressure and high thermal stability, which can enhance the efficiency of CO2 adsorption and capture [37–40]. However, IL-functionalized MOFs are particularly suitable since they can both adsorb large volumes of CO2 and exhibit high catalytic reactivity. [27,28] Imidazolium-based ILs featuring hydroxyl (-OH) and carboxylic (-COOH) groups exhibit remarkable catalytic efficiency in CO2 fixation with epoxides, attributed to their hydrogen bonding with the oxygen atom of epoxides, which leads to its activation and an increase in catalytic activity [41–45]. We reported recently guanidinium-based ionic liquid functionalized MOFs, which demonstrated effective heterogeneous catalytic performances in the CO2 fixation reaction with epoxides, with high yield and selectivity, under mild conditions without co-catalyst and solvent due to the hydrogen bonding and the presence of highly reactive nucleophiles [46,47]. Taherimehr et al. [48] demonstrated the remarkable characteristics of MOFs and ILs by combining MIL-100 with 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide catalysts under 60 °C, 8.0 MPa for 18 h. This combination resulted in an impressive 94 % yield of styrene carbonate, implying a strong synergistic effect between IL and MOF for the cycloaddition reaction. In another study, Ma et al. [49] reported the successful use of tetrabutylammonium bromide-functionalized MIL-101(Cr) as a reusable catalyst. This catalyst proficiently converted CO2 and propylene oxide into propylene carbonate, achieving an outstanding 99 % yield under the reaction conditions of 2.0 MPa and 80 °C for 8 h. The post-synthetic encapsulation technique can be used to load guests or their precursors into the pre-formed cavities or channels of MOFs through exchange or diffusion processes. This technique is often referred to as "ship-in-bottle" encapsulation. The effectiveness of encapsulation relies on ensuring that the size and shape of the MOF pores align with the structure of the guests, along with establishing relatively strong supramolecular interactions between the two components [50]. For example, Liu et al. synthesized an innovative ionic liquid@MOF material by encapsulating an imidazole-based ionic liquid within a hierarchically porous MIL-101(Cr) through the ship-in-bottle approach. [51] Their study revealed that the mobility of active species plays a crucial role in the chemical fixation of CO2. Remarkably, this catalyst exhibited outstanding catalytic properties even without the presence of any co-catalysts, demonstrating its efficacy for the CO2 fixation reaction using acetonitrile as solvent under mild conditions (0.1 MPa, 80 °C). To improve on these catalytic systems, we synthesized novel catalytic materials for CO₂ conversion into cyclic carbonates under mild conditions using MIL-101(Cr) as a support. The parent structure was modified by incorporating newly designed 2-amino pyrimidine moieties linked by alkyl and ether chains. This modification enabled the successful encapsulation of novel ionic liquids (ILs) within the MIL-101(Cr) channels, creating a new catalytic system that enhances both structural integrity and catalytic stability. These newly synthesized materials exhibited exceptional catalytic activity and stability in the cycloaddition of CO₂ to epoxides under mild conditions (0.1 MPa CO₂, 90 °C) without the need for solvents or co-catalysts. While chromium in MIL-101 may raise concerns about cost and environmental impact, the life cycle analysis of the transformation from similar systems shows that these issues are minor compared to factors like energy use, purification, and CO₂ processing conditions [52]. Chromium, being more affordable than palladium, platinum, or rhodium, remains commercially viable if the catalyst is recyclable, energy-efficient, and effective at ambient pressure and low temperatures. Therefore, chromium does not hinder the potential for commercialization. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and instrumentation All solvents and reagents were obtained from commercial sources and used without purification. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis was done using a Rigaku D-Max-Ultima III (Cu Kα, λ = 1.5406 Å) at 293 K. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a Netzsch STA 449 C thermogravimetric analyzer at a heating rate of 5 °C/min with an air flow of 20 mL/min. The CHN elemental analysis was conducted using a Thermo Scientific™ FLASH 2000 CHNS/O analyzer. The infrared spectra were obtained using an ABB MB-3000 Fourier transform spectrometer in the range of 400–4000 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1 and 64 scans. The in-situ FTIR spectroscopy Model React IR15 equipped with MCT detector and DiCOMP probe was used for kinetic study in the scan region of 2500–650 cm−1. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was done using an Inspect F-50 after sputtering with palladium and gold. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) analysis was executed by an Edax Ametek (Octane Super-A). Isotherms of nitrogen adsorption/desorption were achieved via an Autosorb-iQ1 analyzer after degassing at 180 °C for MIL-101(Cr) and 110 °C for functionalized MIL-101(Cr). The Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) equation was employed to compute surface area from adsorption data at P/P0 ranging from 0.05 to 0.2, and the total volume of pores was found from nitrogen adsorption data at P/P0 = 0.95. The CO2 adsorption analysis was performed using a Tristar™ II 3020 at 273 K and 298 K in an ice water bath and a room-temperature water bath, respectively. For the quantification of bromide ions, ICP-MS/MS (Agilent 8900) was used with a helium flow rate of 4.8 mL/min to eliminate mass interferences. Rhodium (Rh) was employed as the internal standard. 2.2 Synthesis of catalysts 2.2.1 Synthesis of MIL-101(Cr) MIL-101(Cr) was synthesized following previously reported procedures [53,54]. In a typical procedure, 10.0 mmol (4.0 g) of Cr(NO3)3·9H2O and 0.6 mL of acetic acid were dissolved in 25 mL of deionized water and stirred for 30 min. Then, 9.87 mmol (1.7 g) of terephthalic acid (H2BDC) was dissolved in 25 mL of deionized water and mixed for 30 min. The two solutions were then combined, stirred for 30 minutes, and placed in a 250 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was then heated in an oven at 220 °C for 8 h. Following this step, a green powder was obtained by vacuum filtration. The product was subsequently purified and activated with 30 mL of deionized water at 80 °C for 4 h, washed with 30 mL of ethanol at 60 °C for 4 h, and heated in a vacuum at 180 °C for 24 h to obtain pure green MIL-101(Cr). The CHN elemental analysis (%) calculated for MIL-101(Cr) (C8H5.6Cr1O5.3): C 40.14, H 2.37. Found: C 40.17, H 2.39. 2.2.2 Synthesis method of MIL101-2AMP-DBrP and MIL101-2AMP-DBrEE The MIL101–2AMP-DBrP and MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE materials were created using the "ship-in-bottle" (SIB) method ( Scheme 1), which is like a previously reported incipient wetness technique [51,55]. Before loading the reagents, MIL-101(Cr) was activated by heating for 12 h at 180 °C under vacuum. 2-Aminopyrimidine (20.0 mmol, 1.9 g) was dissolved in DMF (14 mL) and added dropwise to MIL-101(Cr) (2.2 mmol, 1.6 g) at room temperature. The loaded MIL-101(Cr) was stirred for 24 h under nitrogen and then mixed in a three-necked round-bottom flask with a solution of 9.8 mmol of 1,5-dibromopentane (2.2 g) in 10 mL DMF to prepare MIL101–2AMP-DBrP, or a solution of 9.8 mmol of bis(2-bromoethyl) ether (2.3 g) in 10 mL DMF to prepare MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE. These mixtures were agitated in an oil bath at 80 °C for 48 h under nitrogen. The reaction mixtures were then cooled down to room temperature and the catalysts were segregated through centrifugation and washed with ethanol (3 × 25 mL). Eventually, the solids were dried in a vacuum oven for 24 h at 110 °C. The CHN elemental analysis (%) calculated for MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE (C12H11.66Cr1N2O5.66Br0.66): C 37.91, H 3.07, N 7.37, MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE with 32 % of 2AMP-DBrEE (C9.28H7.59Cr1N0.64O5.44Br0.21): C 39.21, H 2.67, N 3.15. Found: C 39.22, H 2.71, N 3.17. For MIL101–2AMP-DBrP (C12.33H12.33Cr1N2O5.33Br0.66): C 39.1, H 3.26, N 7.39, MIL101–2AMP-DBrP with 33 % of 2AMP-DBrP (C9.43H7.87Cr1N0.66O5.33Br0.22): C 39.69, H 2.76, N 3.24, Found: C 39.71, H 2.77, N 3.26. 2.2.3 Synthesis of quaternary bromide salts To synthesize the pyrimidinium salts, a mixture of 2-aminopyrimidine (12 mmol) and of the bis(alkyl bromide) derivative (6 mmol) was agitated overnight in DMF (10 mL) at 80 °C, leading to the creation of a white precipitate. The product was then isolated by filtration and washed with fresh DMF (2 × 10 mL) and ethanol (5 mL) after cooling to room-temperature [56]. 2.2.3.1 1,5-Bis(2-aminopyrimidinium)pentane bromide (2AMP-DBrP) This compound was prepared from 2-aminopyrimidine and 1,5- dibromopentane. Isolated yield of 72 % (1.81 g, 4.31 mmol). 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO): 8.21 (d, J = 4.8 Hz, 4H), 6.57 (s, 4H), 6.54 (dd, J = 4.8 Hz, 2H), 3.57 (t, J = 6.8 Hz, 4H), 1.83 (quin, J = 6.8 Hz, 4H), 1.51 (m, 2H). 2.2.3.2 1,5-Bis(2-aminopyrimidinium)ethyl ether bromide (2AMP-DBrEE) This compound was prepared from 2-aminopyrimidine and bis(2-bromoethyl)ether. Isolated yield of 67 % (1.72 g, 4.07 mmol). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): 8.28 (d, J = 4.9 Hz, 4H), 6.59 (dd, J = 4.8 Hz, 2H), 5.38 (s, 4H), 3.83 (t, J = 6.3 Hz, 4H), 3.47 (t, J=6.3 Hz, 4H). 2.3 General procedure of CO2 fixation with epoxides To activate the functionalized MOF catalysts for catalytic testing, the guest solvent molecules were eliminated by heating at 100 °C in a vacuum oven for 24 h. Then, a 20 mL batch glass reactor with a magnetic stirring bar was loaded with the selected epoxide (10 mmol) and catalyst (mol%). The CO2 was then introduced into the reactor to achieve the desired pressure, and the mixture was agitated at a constant temperature (ranging from 25 °C to 100 °C) for the desired duration. After the specified time, the reactor was then cooled down to room temperature, the CO2 was removed, and deuterated chloroform was added as the solvent for 1H NMR spectroscopy. The solution was mixed for 30 minutes and then centrifuged to isolate the catalyst. Finally, the products were analyzed using 1H NMR spectroscopy with mesitylene as internal standard. The NMR yields with internal standard were used as they provide a reliable, non-invasive method to quantify both the product and any unreacted starting materials, offering an accurate reflection of the reaction's efficiency without the risk of losing volatile species. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Material synthesis and characterization The MIL-101(Cr) framework, with the general formula Cr3O(OH)(H2O)2(C6H4(COO)2)3, is made up of Cr3O ionic trimeric clusters that coordinate through carboxylate moieties (–COO-) from the terephthalic carboxylate ligand [57,58]. The resultant 3-D structure possesses quasi-spherical cages of 29 Å and 34 Å in diameter that are accessed through apertures of 12 and 16 Å, respectively. MIL-101(Cr) with catalytically active and coordinatively unsaturated sites (CUSs) is formed through the elimination of water molecules that are linked to the metal ions using heat and vacuum treatment [59]. The post-modification of pristine material was done by the subsequent loading of 2-aminopyrimidine and bis(alkylbromide) derivatives into the pores of MIL-101(Cr). A slight heating allows the nucleophilic substitution to take place, creating an ionic liquid within the channels that is firmly enclosed within the pores, even after washing with solvents. The elemental analysis confirmed an incorporation rate of 33 wt% and 32 wt% for 2AMP-DBrP and 2AMP-DBrEE in MIL101–2AMP-DBrP and MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE, respectively. To accurately quantify the bromine ions in the catalyst frameworks, ICP-MS/MS (Agilent 8900) was used. The bromine ion content was 6.7 ± 0.7 % for MIL101–2AMP-DBrP and 5.8 ± 0.6 % for MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE. These results are consistent with those obtained from CHN analysis, confirming the reliable quantification of bromine in the catalysts. The existence of Lewis acidic sites in the MOF structure, hydrogen atoms capable of forming hydrogen bonds, and halide ions in the pores are all structural features required for improved catalytic efficiency in the reaction between CO2 and epoxides. FTIR spectroscopy was employed to investigate the integration of 2AMP-DBrP and 2AMP-DBrEE into MIL-101(Cr) ( Fig. 1). As shown, notable peaks at 1395 cm−1 (symmetric) and 1614 cm−1 (asymmetric) vibrations indicate the existence of carboxylates within both the MIL-101(Cr) framework and the functionalized structure [60,61]. This observation suggests that the structural integrity of MIL-101(Cr) was maintained following the functionalization process. Upon the addition of 2AMP-DBrP and 2AMP-DBrEE, two distinct bands emerge at 3166 and 3334 cm−1, which are characteristic of the N-H stretching of the 2-aminopyrimidinium cation moieties. Furthermore, the peaks observed at 1582 cm−1 and 1280 cm−1 suggest the presence of CN and C-N stretching vibrations in the functional groups, as demonstrated in the case of 2AMP-DBrP and 2AMP-DBrEE [62,63]. These pieces of evidence collectively confirm the formation of 2-amino-pyrimidinium salt derivatives within the structure of MIL-101(Cr). The wide-angle powder X-ray diffractograms of the pristine simulated MIL-101(Cr), synthesized MIL-101(Cr), and functionalized MIL101–2AMP-DBrP and MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE, were examined to confirm the structural integrity of the MOF structure after encapsulation ( Fig. 2). The existence of intense diffraction peaks indicates a proper degree of crystallinity, as anticipated. The PXRD pattern of MIL-101(Cr) exhibits major diffraction peaks at 2θ = 1.91 °, 2.91 °, 3.36 °, 5.23 °, 8.52 °, and 9.13 °, which are in agreement with the simulated PXRD pattern and previously reported data of MIL-101(Cr) [64,65]. The main peaks of the pyrimidinium-based ionic MOFs (MIL101–2AMP-DBrP and MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE) were found at 2θ = 1.81 °, 2.79 °, 3.26 °, 5.13 °, 8.41 °, and 9.02 °, indicating a slightly shifted position towards lower angles than the pristine MOF. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the crystalline powder validate the preservation of MIL-101(Cr) crystalline structure but with a slightly larger unit cell size, probably because of the incorporation of pyrimidinium salt derivatives during post-synthetic modification. The surface of MIL101–2AMP-DBrP and MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE nanocrystals was characterized by XPS analysis to determine the chemical composition and the chemical state information. The survey scans depicted in Fig. 3a confirmed the presence of O, C, N, Cr, and Br atoms. The nitrogen 1s spectrum (Fig. 3(b and c)) shows distinct peaks at 399.9 eV, corresponding to non-ionic nitrogen atoms such as the NH₂ group and nitrogen within the pyrimidinium ring, and at 400.7 eV, attributed to the positively charged nitrogen atom in the pyrimidinium ring. [51,66]. Moreover, the bromine 3d spectrum displayed peaks at 69.1/67.9 eV and 67.1/66.0 eV (Fig. 3d and e), aligning with the binding energies of bromide ions. This collective evidence strongly suggests the successful synthesis and integration of ionic liquids (2AMP-DBrP and 2AMP-DBrEE) into the MIL-101(Cr) framework. The thermal stability of MIL-101(Cr), MIL101–2AMP-DBrP, and MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE was investigated using the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) under air flow of 20 mL/min, as shown in Fig. 4. The TGA curves display weight loss occurring in three steps for functionalized Cr-MOFs. The first thermal event occurred at temperatures ranging from 242 °C to 353 °C, with weight losses of 16.1 % for MIL101–2AMP-DBrP and 15.6 % for MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE, attributed to the degradation of 2AMP-DBrP and 2AMP-DBrEE, respectively. The second thermal event occurs at 353 °C, with weight losses of 56.1 % and 57.7 % for MIL101–2AMP-DBrP and MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE, respectively. The same thermal process was observed for MIL-101(Cr), with a weight loss of 63.3 %. This second process can be associated to the degradation of the terephthalate linkers. These results indicate that the MIL101–2AMP-DBrP and MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE composites exhibit thermal stability below 240 °C. The pristine and modified MIL-101(Cr) catalysts were examined to assess their morphology and chemical composition using SEM images and EDS data, which are presented in Fig. 5. As shown, the MIL-101(Cr) exhibits an octahedral shape with particles of uniform size ranging from 250 to 340 nm. Importantly, even after incorporating 2AMP-DBrP and 2AMP-DBrEE, the framework integrity remains well-preserved with uniform size ranging from 190 to 306 nm, highlighting MIL-101(Cr) skeleton stability. The decrease in particle size of MIL-101(Cr) upon incorporation of 2AMP-DBrP and 2AMP-DBrEE likely originates from the intrinsic flexibility of the MIL-101(Cr) framework, which is known to undergo a 'breathing effect' in response to guest molecule interactions. This effect can lead to structural contraction due to the interaction between the MOF and the ionic liquid, which induces partial framework shrinkage while maintaining structural integrity. Specifically, the centrifugation step applies mechanical energy, which can fragment larger particles into smaller ones. Additionally, mixing during the modification process further contributes to size reduction. The successful introduction of pyrimidinium salt derivatives into MIL-101(Cr) is confirmed by comparing the EDS spectra of MIL-101(Cr) and functionalized MIL-101(Cr) (Fig. S3-S5). To assess the textural properties of the prepared materials, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were conducted at 77 K for activated MIL-101(Cr), MIL101–2AMP-DBrP, and MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE, as displayed in Fig. 6a and summarized in Table 1. The nitrogen adsorption isotherms for all the pristine and functionalized MIL-101(Cr) were fully reversible, with sharp N2 uptake at low partial relative pressures (P/P0 > 0.9) corresponding to a typical type I isotherm as expected for a microporous MOF [67]. Furthermore, the isotherms displayed secondary uptakes between partial relative pressures (P/P0) of 0.1 and 0.2, implying the presence of two nanoporous windows. The BET surface area and pore volume of MIL-101(Cr) were calculated to be 3425 m2 g−1 and 1.78 cm3 g−1, respectively, which are consistent with the reported values [68–70]. However, the incorporation of pyrimidinum-based ILs into the pristine MIL-101(Cr) structure led to a reduction in the surface area and available pore volume in MIL101–2AMP-DBrP (to 2456 m2 g−1 and 1.44 cm3 g−1, respectively) and MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE (to 2408 m2 g−1 and 1.41 cm3 g−1, respectively), as anticipated [55,71]. The nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) was employed to calculate the pore size distribution (PSD). Fig. 6b illustrates the PSD results for pristine MIL-101(Cr), MIL101–2AMP-DBrP and MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE. These materials exhibit micropores and mesopores within the 10–25 Å range. The MIL101-MOFs demonstrated pore sizes at 14.1, 17.7, 20.2 Å, and 24.19 Å. Importantly, all samples have similar pore size nodes, suggesting that during functionalization, some micropores were filled while others remained empty. The CO2 adsorption capacities of MIL-101(Cr) (pristine MIL-101(Cr), MIL101–2AMP-DBrP, and MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE) were compared at 298 K and 273 K under 0.1 MPa, as shown in Fig. 7 and summarized in Table 1. The results indicate that the functionalized MIL-101(Cr) had improved CO2 adsorption compared to the pristine MIL-101(Cr) at both temperatures. Furthermore, the adsorption of CO2 increased as the temperature decreased, which can be explained by the exothermic adsorption on a clean surface. Under 0.1 MPa at 298 K, MIL-101(Cr), MIL101–2AMP-DBrP, and MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE adsorbed 2.64, 3.51, and 4.05 mmol g−1 of CO2, respectively. Similarly, at 273 K, the same adsorbents adsorbed 4.61, 5.27, and 6.35 mmol g−1 of CO2, respectively. These results suggest that loading pyrimidinium salt derivatives (2AMP-DBrP and 2AMP-DBrEE) increased CO2 adsorption, even though the porosity of the MOF decreased. This indicates a favorable interaction between CO2 and loaded 2-amino-pyrimidinium salt derivatives, the basic sites of which are beneficial for CO2 capture. Similar results have been reported with basic moieties such as PEI [68] and PANI [72]. Since the loading of 2AMP-DBrEE and 2AMP-DBrP is approximately the same (32 wt% - 33 wt%), the higher adsorbed amount of CO2 over MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE than over MIL101–2AMP-DBrP suggests that the rise in adsorption capacity is related to the oxygen on the ether linkage. 3.2 Catalytic performance The multifunctional impact of pyrimidinium ionic MIL-101(Cr) was evaluated by testing its performance in catalyzing the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with epoxides without any solvent and co-catalyst. To produce chloropropene carbonate (CPC), 10 mmol of epichlorohydrin (ECH) was used as a model substrate, and the reaction was conducted at 90 °C and a CO2 pressure of 0.1 MPa. The results, summarized in Table 2, demonstrate that without a catalyst or in the presence of Cr(NO3)3, the desired product cannot be produced (entries 1 and 2). Under similar conditions, the pristine MIL-101(Cr) or ILs (2AMP-DBrP, 2AMP-DBrEE) presents a relatively low yield of 22 %, 45 % and 56 %, respectively (Table 2, entries 2–4). When a physical mixture of 2AMP-DBrP or 2AMP-DBrEE with either Cr(NO3)3 or MIL-101(Cr), keeping the molar concentration of bromide and metal site constant, yields of the desired product ranging from 77 % to 88 % were obtained (entries 6–9). However, MIL101–2AMP-DBrP and MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE exhibited outstanding catalytic performance in the cycloaddition reaction under 0.1 MPa at 90 °C for 12 h, yielding 96 % and 99 %, respectively (Table 2, entries 12 and 15). While the ligand and the MOF structure are both catalytically active, the efficiency of MIL101–2AMP-DBrP and MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE illustrates that the framework, multifunctional sites from pyrimidinium cation, bromide anion and the Lewis acid sites from MIL-101(Cr) can work synergistically to improve the catalytic activity. To compare the performance of the catalytic material with previously reported catalysts in CO₂ fixation reactions, the turnover frequency (TOF) is calculated based on the metal sites and the amount of halide ions (Br⁻) present in the ionic liquid (IL) functionalized MOF. The halide ions (Br⁻), acting as the active sites in the MOF structure, were determined using CHN analysis. Running the reaction for various reaction time (6 h, 12 h and 24 h) did show that there is a slight increase in TOF for catalyst MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE and the corresponding ionic liquid 2AMP-DBrEE (entries 5, 13–15) than for catalyst MIL101–2AMP- DBrP and corresponding MIL101–2AMP- DBrP (entries 4, 10–12). These results suggest that the presence of the ether moiety in the ionic liquid plays a positive role in catalysis, probably by increasing the interaction with CO2, as shown in the CO2 adsorption studies. To optimize the reaction conditions for synthesizing chloropropene carbonate (CPC), MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE was utilized at 0.1 MPa CO2 while varying the temperature and reaction time. Fig. 8a displays the effect of temperature, revealing that the apparent CPC yield after 24 h improved from 24 % to > 99 % as the temperature increased from 30 to 90 °C. Raising the temperature to 110 °C did not impact the yield of CPC. Additionally, Fig. 8b demonstrates that extending the reaction duration up to 12 h at 90 °C increased the CPC yield, but no notable alteration in the yield was observed upon further extending the reaction time. Ultimately, the ideal reaction conditions for the CO2 cycloaddition reaction were determined to be 90 °C, 0.1 MPa CO2, and 12 h. To ensure the reliability of the catalytic data, CO₂ fixation reactions were performed using epichlorohydrin with MIL101–2AMP-DBr on a gram scale. Specifically, 1.4 g (1.64 mmol) of MIL101–2AMP-DBrP and 350 mmol of epichlorohydrin were used under 0.1 MPa, at 90 °C, for 12 hours. The in situ FTIR analysis confirmed the formation of cyclic carbonate, as evidenced by the appearance of new peaks at 1801 cm⁻¹ (ν(CO)), 1160 cm⁻¹ (ν(OCO)), and 1070 cm⁻¹ (ν(C–O)). The reaction yielded 99 %, ensuring the reliability of the catalytic data. The performance of the two catalysts was explored using different epoxides under the optimized conditions determined for the carbonation of epichlorohydrin (0.47 mol% of MIL101–2AMP-DBrP and MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE, 0.1 MPa CO2, 90 °C, 12 h). For terminal epoxides without activating groups, catalytic data for propylene oxide are presented, demonstrating the system's efficiency for these challenging substrates. The inclusion of additional epoxides such as ethylene oxide was not feasible due to safety or resource constraints ( Table 3, entries 1 and 2). As can be seen in Table 3, terminal epoxides bearing both electron-withdrawing and electron-donating groups can be transformed into their respective cyclic carbonates with elevated yields of > 94 % for MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE and > 92 % for MIL101–2AMP-DBrP within 12 h, at a temperature of 90 °C and under 0.1 MPa CO2 pressure (entries 3–6). However, for internal cyclohexene oxide, the conversion remains limited. The lower conversion of cyclohexene oxide in CO2 fixation reactions compared to terminal epoxides is due to several key factors. First, steric hindrance from its cyclic structure reduces access to the catalyst's active sites, unlike terminal epoxides, which have more open structures. Additionally, cyclohexene oxide has lower ring strain, making the epoxide ring less reactive and harder to open compared to terminal epoxides. Its electronic properties also contribute to reduced reactivity, as it lacks strong electron-withdrawing groups that can stabilize intermediates. Finally, diffusion limitations may arise due to its bulkier nature, making it harder for cyclohexene oxide to reach the active sites, particularly in porous catalysts like MOFs [34,47,73]. To further identify the potential of the MIL101–2AMP-DBrP and MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates, their catalytic activity was compared with that of previously documented IL-supported MIL-101(Cr) and other typical MOF materials in the CO2 fixation reaction with epichlorohydrin. The comparative data are presented in Table 4, with the TOF values determined based on the molar ratio of epoxide to halide. As shown in Table 4, the cyclic carbonate can be effectively produced using MIL-101-tzmOH-Br and PolyIL@MIL-101 catalysts, achieving a favorable yield even at moderately mild reaction temperatures (80 and 70 °C) and low-pressure conditions (0.1 MPa). However, these reactions exhibited noticeably reduced TOF values (as shown in entries 12–15, Table 4) [74,75]. Several imidazolium and guanidinium-based IL functionalized UiO-66, UiO-67 and FJI-C10 were also used in this catalytic transformation [27,47,76–79]. Under almost the same conditions, MIL101–2AMP-DBrP and MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE demonstrated significantly higher catalytic activity compared to FJI-C10 and UiO67-IL (entries 3 and 9, Table 4). Similarly, UiO67-[TBD]+Br-, (I-)Meim-UiO-66, UiO66Pym-MeI and UiO67BPym-MeI required longer time for the conversion of epichlorohydrin (ECH) into the corresponding cyclic carbonate (entries 1, 2, 4 and 5, Table 4). The comparison suggested that MIL101–2AMP-DBrP and MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE have significantly higher catalytic activity, by almost an order of magnitude, under mild conditions (0.1 MPa, 90 °C, 12 h, without solvent and co-catalyst). 3.3 Reusability of the MIL101-2AMP-DBrEE The stability and recyclability of heterogeneous catalysts are fundamental features that are indispensable for their use in industrial applications. The reusability of MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE was evaluated by examining its ability to catalyze the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with epichlorohydrin under optimal reaction conditions for 5 catalytic cycles. After each cycle, the reaction mixture was extracted with CDCl3 (3 mL) and the solid catalyst was recovered by centrifugation, washed with ethanol (3 × 10 mL), and dried at 90 °C for 12 h before being reused under similar reaction conditions. The results, illustrated in Fig. 9a, indicate that the catalyst retains its activity and remains stable even after 5 catalytic cycles, with yields and conversion being consistent throughout. Furthermore, comparison of the PXRD analysis of the fresh and reused samples showed a similar pattern, demonstrating the stability of MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE (Fig. 9b). To determine whether homogenous catalysis was involved, a leaching test was carried out during the first run. After 3 h, the catalytic CO2 fixation reaction was halted, and MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE was isolated from the reaction mixture. The filtrate was then agitated for an additional 12 h, and the filtrate showed no indication of any progress in the CO2 fixation reaction after 12 h. To confirm the stable encapsulation of the dicationic ionic liquid following the CO2 cycloaddition reaction, we also conducted elemental analysis. The recycled MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE exhibited a N element content of 3.11 wt%, which closely resembled the fresh catalyst's value of 3.17 wt%. These results suggest that there was almost no leaching of MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE nanocages over 5 reaction cycles. The obtained characterization results clearly demonstrate the encapsulation of the ionic liquid 2AMP-DBrEE within the MIL-101(Cr) nanocages, highlighting its stable confinement and confirming the heterogeneous nature of the reaction and its promising implications. To gain a deeper insight into the reaction mechanism, the CO2 fixation reaction with epichlorohydrin using 2AMP-DBrP as catalyst was monitored using in situ FTIR for 5 h at 90 °C and 0.1 MPa ( Fig. 10). As depicted in the Fig. 10a, the formation of cyclic carbonate is evidenced by the formation of new peaks at 1801 cm−1 (ν(CO)), 1160 cm−1 (ν(OCO)), and at 1070 cm−1 (ν(C–O)), which are well-matched with the spectrum of chloropropene carbonate in Fig. 10b [79,80]. To interpret the data accurately, the peak at 1801 cm−1 was deconvoluted into distinct peaks using Gaussian function as fitting model. Following this process, a new peak emerges at 1762 cm−1, indicating the formation of a new COOH group resulting from the interaction of CO2 with the primary amine of 2AMP-DBrP, which gradually increases during the reaction, suggesting the generation of carbamic acid. Notably, both the absorption peaks associated with the carbonyl group at 1762 cm−1, indicative of carbamic acid, and the peak at 1801 cm−1, associated with chloropropene carbonate, exhibit a gradual increase over the reaction time. This observation suggests the activation of CO2 by the primary amino group in the ionic liquid, thereby significantly enhancing the CO2 fixation reaction with epoxide. 3.4 Possible reaction mechanism According to the experimental evidence from in situ FTIR studies, catalytic data for various substrates (including terminal epoxide such as propylene oxide), structural features of MIL101–2AMP-DBrP, as well as previous reports [73,79,81], a mechanism for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides over MIL101–2AMP-DBrP is proposed in Scheme 2. First, the primary amino groups in the pyrimidinium moiety of MIL101–2AMP-DBrP act as nitrogen-donor Lewis basic sites and coordinate to CO2 to afford the carbamic acid as an activated form of CO2 (a). As shown in the CO2 adsorption studies, the enhancement of CO2 capture within the MIL101–2AMP-DBrP framework results in an increased concentration of carbon dioxide within the porous structure [82]. Simultaneously, activation of the epoxide may occur through hydrogen bonding between the epoxide oxygen and the carbamic acid. The epoxide is further activated via coordination of its oxygen atom to the Lewis acid sites of Cr in MIL-101(Cr). The bromide anion (Br⁻) can then do a nucleophilic attack on the less sterically hindered carbon atom of the epoxide to open it, forming a bromoalcohol (b). Next, a hydrogen transfer from the alcohol to the nitrogen atom of 2AMP-DBrP is occurring as the alcoholate interacts with the CO2 of the carbamic moiety to generate the bromoalkylcarbonate anion (c). In the final step, an intramolecular ring-closing reaction occurs, leading to the formation of the cyclic carbonate product and the regeneration of MIL101–2AMP-DBrP catalyst (e), allowing it to be used again in the next catalytic cycle. The proposed mechanism, supported by consistent catalytic trends observed across various substrates, highlights its broad applicability. However, due to technical limitations, in situ FTIR measurements for more volatile substrates, such as propylene oxide, could not be performed. 4 Conclusion In summary, MIL-101(Cr) was utilized to encapsulate new ionic pyrimidinium salts via a ship-in-bottle synthetic method, marking a significant advancement in CO₂ conversion with an innovative and efficient catalyst design. The resulting modified MOFs, MIL101–2AMP-DBrP and MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE, exhibited enhanced CO2 adsorption at low pressures and demonstrated superior catalytic capabilities for CO2 conversion with various epoxides. Notably, these MOFs achieve a high turnover frequency (TOF) of 82.5 h⁻¹ under mild conditions (atmospheric pressure, 90 °C), without the need for co-catalysts or solvents, which are important criteria for the commercialization of such catalyst for industrial applications. The presence of bromide ions and hydrogen bonding within the pore structure facilitated epoxide ring opening, enhancing catalytic efficiency. In situ FTIR analysis revealed that primary amino groups activated CO₂ through carbamic acid formation, while the ionic liquid increased the density of CO2 in the vicinity of active sites. Additionally, the ether group slightly boosted activity, aiding CO₂ activation at atmospheric pressure. Furthermore, MIL-101–2AMP-DBrEE demonstrated excellent durability and ease of separation during repeated CO₂ cycloaddition cycles. This innovative approach holds promise for developing new and efficient catalysts for CO₂ utilization in various industrial applications. coredata.dc:description: Modified metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) encapsulating new ionic N-heterocyclic-based functional groups, prepared via a ship-in-a-bottle approach, introduce a novel catalytic system for CO₂ conversion with epoxides. The MIL-101(Cr) framework was functionalized with novel ionic liquids (ILs) such as 1,5-bis(2-aminopyrimidinium)pentane bromide (2AMP-DBrP) and 1,5-bis(2-aminopyrimidinium)ethyl ether bromide (2AMP-DBrEE), resulting in cationic pyrimidinium-containing Cr-MOFs with free bromide ions, namely MIL101–2AMP-DBrP and MIL101–2AMP-DBrEE. Although the surface area (2456 and 2408 m²/g) and pore volume (1.44 and 1.41 cm³/g) of these encapsulated materials were reduced compared to pristine MIL-101(Cr) (3425 m²/g and 1.78 cm³/g), the CO₂ adsorption capacity at low pressure was notably increased (3.51 and 4.05 mmol g⁻¹ of CO₂). These modified MOFs demonstrated exceptional catalytic performance and stability in CO₂ fixation with various epoxides, achieving a high turnover frequency (TOF) of 82.5 h⁻¹ under mild conditions (0.1 MPa, 90 °C) without the need for co-catalysts or solvents, which are essential criteria for commercial viability. Moreover, in situ FTIR analysis suggests that the enhanced performance is due to CO₂ activation via carbamic acid formation facilitated by primary amino groups and epoxide activation through hydrogen bonding. This dual activation mechanism is critical for achieving high catalytic efficiency under mild conditions and underscores the innovative and significant advancements presented in this work compared to existing IL-MOFs.
